column4: Seems like that grub page I got referred to only has information useful for those who already have GRUB installed. But it's OK for me to reinstall Ubuntu.
I want to select the correct partition for GRUB. I found out that my root partition is on sdb1. Should I select (sdb1) as boot loader drive then?
Do you have only the 1 drive in your system?
I have an external harddrive.

What I mean is, is the sda drive the only hard drive which you are using for an operating system? If not, and you have some IDE drive for instance which normally boots and is seen as hda   then you would normally want the grub install to be hda  (NOTE, NOT hda1) Please also note that not to install grub to a subpartition eg sda1 sda2 etc) just sda for instance
If the drive it sees as sda is the one it was trying to boot from before you put ubuntu on, then just put for grub sda (NOTE, NOT sda1 or sda2 or so on just sda)
I'm going to boot from the external hard drive using the computers own boot device selection menu.
Is there a hard drive which normally wants to boot when the computer starts?
I can choose my self.
Keep in mind if you switch the boot order in bios it screws the hard drive assignments that the drives got. sda might become after adc or weird stuff like so
If you are making the removable drive the default boot drive in bios after setting it up with linux when the order was different, it will be trying to load from a drive that it cannot find
I'm trying to make ubuntu-on-a-usb-hard-drive. So I can bring it anywhere.
Yes, but when you installed it (the OS) to sdb, after you switched the bootup order in bios, it now thinks it's drive name is sda instead.
However, this can be fixed

If you can access the usb drive from another linux install or the livecd, you can edit the files /boot/grub/menu.lst   and /etc/fstab   to change hd1 to hd0 in the menu.lst and sdb to sda in the /etc/fstab

Good :) The changes will be for grub to hd0 from the old hd1 (corresponding to sdb) and in the fstab from sdb to sda
